That Supermarionation technique that came

Supermarionation is a
term that Gerry Anderson

161.20.text:

sell this idea that

164.37.text:
you're making this very sophisticated form
of puppetry. This is not your Andy Pandy

167.08.text:

171.83.text:

176.20.text:
with painted-on eyes

178.62.text:
This is a very sophisticated, higher

184.83.text:
When they were doing it in the sixties,

Gerry Anderson hated being

190.83.text:
And the goal of that team was: Make

195.91.text:
- Have depth to the sets.
- Film them like people:

198.33.text:

200.08.text:

998.54.text:
The model work in Thunderbirds
and all those types of shows

1001.54.text:
is very specific. There's a very specific
way that they make their planes fly

1006.50.text:
that they make their cars
drive, the way they film it.

1009.70.text:
Very of its time in terms
of the grammar of the way a

1012.66.text:
craft are so often going left
to right or right to left.

1015.45.text:
The modern way of film
making is to make you feel

1019.37.text:
you're traveling much more with the vehicle
or much more in the centre of action.

1022.54.text:
Whereas the Derek Meddings
style is you're an observer.

1026.70.text:
If you go back to Thunderbirds, they
would make their models filthy.

1031.04.text:
It's a technique Derek Meddings
in the sixties perfected

1035.25.text:
and they had this great eye for
making things look realistic.

1040.12.text:
It's a key to the
filming of the models.

1042.62.text:
When does Thunderbird 4 look the best?
When it is absolutely filthy.

1046.20.text:
It looks like it
actually had gone out on

1047.79.text:
missions. So our models
we would dirty them down

1050.66.text:
and put them on camera
and quite often

1052.95.text:
there was a building or
vehicle and you would

1055.33.text:
look at it and go, "Oh...
it's not dirty enough."

1057.33.text:
So if you see a model
under normal light

1061.50.text:
it looks very worn and dirty. But in
front of a camera, when you lit it

1066.41.text:
you lose about 70% of
the dirtying down.

1069.37.text:
So it is a skill to look through
the camera and make a judgment

1073.20.text:
as to the amount of
breaking down of the model.

1076.12.text:
If you put something in front
of the camera that must

1078.25.text:
appear brand new, you still
have to dirty it down.

1080.83.text:
If it looks right on camera,
then that's what it has to be.

1085.12.text:
Even if you pick the model up and
it looks like a piece of rubbish.

1088.37.text:
As long as it looks good on camera, it can
be very flimsy, only detailed on one side.

1094.00.text:
The long time appeal of Thunderbirds is
in the fact that it is not about realism.

1098.00.text:
We're not kidding ourselves or anybody –
we know when you look at these effect shots

1101.95.text:
no one is going to think it is real life.

1105.66.text:

1114.62.text:

1117.79.text:
Not for one second do you buy that

1121.75.text:

1123.87.text:

1127.75.text:

1284.75.text:
Say, FAB 1 sure is
a great automobile.

1287.79.text: We like it, don't we, Parker?

1291.50.text:
We had to recreate FAB1
which is probably one

1294.91.text:
of the most difficult
puppet sized props

1296.87.text:
they even had on the
original series.

1298.79.text:
So we were loaned
sections of a FAB 1 model

1302.58.text:
which we then had to modify.
And I just happened to have

1306.58.text:
from 20 years ago some casts from the
original Thunderbirds Are Go FAB 1

1312.33.text:
which I then reworked to make it look
like something of the first series car.

1316.37.text:
I can't think of another series where
people have attempted to bring it back and

1320.25.text:
do it exactly the same way. Maybe because
most of the time it's not possible.

1323.79.text:
If you suddenly decided
to remake, say,

1329.25.text:
you wouldn't have the actors around so in
that sense it would be an impossible feat.

1333.12.text:
For us, with these recordings, with the
fact that our stars are made of fibreglass

1337.41.text:
whether they are puppet or vehicle,
that is something we can do.

1341.45.text:
If we were producing a new marionette
series, it would be a lot easier

1346.91.text:
than what we are trying to
do now: Making an exact

1349.50.text:
recreation of what was
made five decades ago.

1353.75.text:
If the slightest thing
is off, everything is

1356.20.text:
thrown. You're suddenly
not in the sixties.

1358.66.text:
There are all sorts of
things that are part of

1360.08.text:
recreation that you can't
really put your finger on.

1362.16.text:
You look at a shot and
it either looks like.

1364.25.text:
Thunderbirds or it doesn't
look like Thunderbirds...

1366.83.text:
or it sort-of looks like
Thunderbirds. Which

1368.79.text:
is the worst kind of
shot because you go,

1371.00.text:
"What's the thing that's
letting it down? Is

1373.25.text:
it the lighting? Is it
the puppet's face?"

1376.87.text:
Getting it as close to
what it was is very

1378.95.text:
important. I think there
is that added pressure.

1382.37.text:
Unlike if we were making something
different, in that we'd think,

1386.20.text:
'This is what we want, but is
it what they would have done?'

1389.08.text:
And it has to be the way
they would have done.

1391.12.text:
Particularly building something that has to
appear, not a recreation of Thunderbird 2,

1397.04.text:
not a recreation of a puppet, but those
little bits of detailing. Sets...

1400.20.text:
Sets made especially made
for this production.

1402.70.text:
They need to be made
in a way to looks like

1405.29.text:
they could have been
made in the sixties.

1407.29.text:
One of our big problems is sometimes
people who have supplied stuff –

1410.37.text:
they make it too well. And that's not
to run down the original series.

1414.70.text:
We're doing this using
some modern technology

1419.04.text:
and it would be tempting to try and
update the way we're doing things.

1423.25.text:
But we have to keep bringing
it back to the sixties.

1426.20.text:
I met Stephen and Geraldine because we were
appearing together in a play in Geneva,

1431.66.text:
which I was doing costumes for. And Stephen
sidled up to me towards the end and said,

1435.95.text:
"Would you be interested in
doing something a bit bizarre?"

1452.87.text:
Our costume lady Liz was thrown
in the deep side of the pool

1457.12.text:
when we told her,
"Now you've got so many weeks

1461.16.text:
"we want so many costumes, they have to be
teeny-tiny, they have to fit perfectly,

1464.91.text:
"they have to have the right
pattern, and we want them sixties...

1469.75.text:
"Get to it now." – And she managed great.
We got so many costumes

1473.20.text:
from her. They alll look fantastic. The
attention to detail is really good.

1478.25.text:
To research it I was more looking
at costumes of the sixties

1481.87.text:
than the Thunderbirds costumes. And
looking at the Thunderbirds costumes

1486.87.text:
you can see they got excited by
all these new futuristic fabrics

1492.29.text:
like polyester which is
why so many costumes are

1496.08.text:
rigid on the original
Thunderbirds marionettes

1499.04.text:
because polyester has
very little give.

1501.58.text:
What really works well is anything
that is a tad on the stretch side

1505.87.text:
so for example this
has some elasticity to it.

1512.12.text:
It is not easy to find details
and patterns that work

1516.62.text:
for puppets. These stripes
for example would look

1520.08.text:
massive and the puppet
would look puppet sized.

1523.95.text:
We did find some. Like
Jeff's flamingo shirt,

1527.83.text:
which is just gorgeous.
And is perfect for Jeff.

1530.37.text:
But you think 'What would
anyone in the real world

1533.70.text:
'want to use a quarter centimeter high
flamingoes on a bit of fabric for?'

1539.54.text:
Very bizarre. Can't work
that one out at all.

1542.08.text:
You can tell Jeff's costumes. There
is something a bit kind of odd about them.

1547.79.text:
He's got a bit of a peacock in him,
which again is a very sixties thing.

1551.75.text:
There was this thing called
the Peacock Revolution.

1553.87.text:
Bring the luggage,
will you Parker?

1555.95.text:
Yes, M'Lady. I'll have
to make several trips.

1559.50.text: You've brought a lot of gear.

1561.70.text:
Parker, when one's visiting,
one tries to look one's best.

1567.16.text:
To be honest, I don't
like Lady Penelope.

1569.25.text: I really don't. She's a stupid,

1573.00.text:
unnatural size, And you have to keep saying
"She's not Barbie, she's not Barbie,"

1581.87.text:
But she's shaped like Barbie. I was quite happy when I
could make her slightly formal, more masculine clothes.

1592.16.text:
Well, I must say Parker. It was a good
idea of yours to bring FAB 1 along.

1599.95.text:
I knew it would be as close
to the 1960s experience –

1604.00.text:
making the original series –
as much as would be possible,

1607.00.text:
but it completely surpassed
my expectations.

1611.20.text:
Probably one the strangest
parts was bringing back people

1613.75.text:
who'd worked on the
original series.

1615.54.text:
Specifically David
Elliot to direct and

1618.20.text:
Mary Turner who came in to
puppeteer for a couple of days.

1632.75.text:
It reminds me of
the earlier days

1637.79.text:
It's weird. As soon as I opened the door I
was at home. It doesn't feel any different.

1648.70.text:
It's incredible when David and Mary
were working together, because

1652.12.text:
they both immediately came back
to their working relationship

1657.29.text: they'd had all those years ago.

1658.95.text:
We've been very lucky. We've
been friends for over 50 years.

1665.20.text: You soon get back into it again.

1667.66.text:
To be honest, you've
never gone out of it.

1670.70.text:
Are you ready? – Yeah.
– Running! Action!

1674.83.text:
And he manages to knock out
the automatic TV cameras too.

1679.16.text:
Exactly. It's almost
as if he's a phantom.

1687.66.text:
Yeah. That's the one. Print! Print!
Cool.

1691.83.text:
Every single shot we do
takes a lot of preparation.

1698.16.text:
before you actually get
it before the camera.

1700.25.text:
David Tremont for instance, spent a good
few weeks building this beautiful mansion

1704.95.text:
that we knew was going to
be blown up in seconds.

1707.58.text:
The most exciting thing has
to be the mansion exploding.

1715.70.text:
The initial stages is sitting down with
the directors, designers, whomever,

1720.95.text:
and getting out of their heads what
they see – what they imagine it to be.

1726.12.text:
What sort of explosion, how big
can we can make the model.

1729.62.text:
It has to be built specifically,
so it destructs in a certain way.

1733.83.text:
You don't want the model
to go "pffff" like that.

1736.70.text:
You want bits of it to fly off, you want
debrie flying off towards the camera.

1741.04.text:
That's a huge staple of
Thunderbirds explosions.

1743.41.text:
Little things flying
away towards the camera.

1745.58.text:
You have to build it extremely fragile.
There is a lot more technology

1751.12.text:
that goes into making
something come apart.

1754.50.text:
And when we put the trees
in, it looks fantastic.

1757.54.text:
And people, when we mentioned, "Hey, look
at this... isn't it beautiful..." would be

1761.70.text:
appalled when we said,
"It's going to be blown up!

1763.62.text:
It's not going
to exist next week!"

1765.00.text:
I get this a lot. I've built
many pyro-models over the years.

1769.91.text:
And the first reaction is always "You
don't want to see your model destroyed".

1774.70.text:
But no, completely
opposite to that.

1776.83.text:
A pyro-model is purpose
built to be destroyed.

1779.91.text:
That's the whole challenge
of the project.

1782.04.text:
When we try to recreate the
kind of explosions that

1785.04.text:
Derek Meddings and his team
produced for the original Thunderbirds

1788.37.text:
there is a specific look to them. Often
because they used quite dangerous things.

1792.79.text:
Some of the chemicals were
carcinogenic which we cannot use now,

1796.16.text:
but those chemicals produced
very specific sorts of looks.

1800.41.text:
Black smoke turns up everywhere in
Thunderbirds when there is an explosion –

1803.62.text:
there is usually this toxic
stuff you would not want

1805.50.text:
to breath in and cannot use
now because it's illegal.

1808.41.text:
One of the challenges for
our pyro-technicians

1810.79.text:
was to go away and look
at what they were doing

1812.87.text:
and then try and come up with the
equivalent of what they were using

1816.66.text:
so we could achieve the
same sort of look.

1820.04.text:
It requires working a lot
with the pyro-technicians

1823.41.text:
designing what sort of explosion, what
sort of sequences, how many, how big.

1828.20.text:
That's the larger charge
we would suspend in a roof

1831.45.text:
to blow the roof off
and the timbers.

1835.12.text:
And then we have
others here that will

1838.70.text:
fire vertically in the air and
producing flame at the same time.

1842.79.text:
The pyro guys come in and put
all their charges into it.

1846.66.text:
Once they're all finished,
they move out and I go in

1849.45.text:
and I fill every gap
I can with debris.

1852.12.text:
Tremont spent weeks and weeks
building this model and

1855.20.text:
it's all in one shot. It's going
to blow up. And if it doesn't work

1860.70.text:
So we actually put two cameras on
it, just in case, to make sure

1863.20.text:
that we got it. Because we would
never be able to set it up again.

1866.95.text: So you just hope that it works.

1870.70.text:
So when it exploded
it just went "pow".

1885.25.text:
If you were to come into the studio and
watch us shooting the special effects

1889.25.text:
to be honest it all looks a bit rinky-dink.
When we set off an explosion

1893.45.text:
it's not a huge fireball.
It's a puff and it's gone.

1899.41.text:
That's why shooting it at
high speed is very important.

1903.25.text:
You're shooting at a
higher frame rate

1905.25.text:
than normal film. Normal film
runs at 24 frames per second.

1908.66.text:
So in 1 second you get
24 separate images

1912.66.text:
that are taken by the camera.
With high speed photography

1915.62.text:
you could be doing 120 frames
per second for our explosion shots.

1920.41.text:
It's a lot of pictures
within that one second.

1922.87.text:
You play that back at 24 frames per second
and everything happens really slowly.

1926.79.text:
A tiny little "puff" becomes
a really big "woooof".

1949.66.text:
And that applies to
the models as well.

1952.25.text:
When you've got models on strings
flying across the screen

1955.29.text: they tend to bump and wobble.

1957.29.text:
If you shoot it at high speed
and then play it back normally

1960.37.text:
the bumps and wobbles become
a sort of gentle turbulence.

1964.66.text:
It feels right. The craft
have weight. They feel

1967.50.text:
like they are actually
suspended in mid-air.

1970.08.text:
I think the original AP
Films film crew formed

1972.29.text:
a family. Particularly
in the earlier days

1974.08.text:
running up to and
including Thunderbirds.

1976.29.text:
Supermarionation is such a
silly form of film making.

1978.79.text:
As great as it looks on
screen, the actual day-to-day

1981.50.text:
process of it, the reality
is so silly that it would be

1983.87.text:
very difficult not to form some sort
of camaraderie with the team around you

1989.33.text:
and to all work together to make this
has been a very special experience.

1994.83.text:
I think this type of film
making, with puppets,

1998.16.text:
visual effects – has
definitely got a future.

2001.20.text:
It's telling that every
time Thunderbirds has made

2003.20.text:
a comeback to different
generations of children

2006.20.text:
each generation has
taken to it so much.

2008.75.text:
Doing something using these almost
extinct Supermarionation techniques

2013.66.text:
isn't just a matter
of nostalgia.

2016.75.text:
It can't be. There are a lot of fans on our
crew. But there are a lot of professionals

2020.91.text:
who don't have a particular
childhood fondness for the series

2024.70.text:
and they are all able
to see the appeal.

2028.75.text:
I think it has a huge future,
because it's a physical art.

2034.45.text:
Absolutely all the traditional
arts should be retained

2037.66.text:
should be passed on,
should be taught, to the

2040.45.text:
next generation of
special effects artists.

2043.12.text:
To be embracing what they were doing
50 years ago is very important

2046.37.text:
because we are the last
generation doing this.

2049.08.text:
And this is a real old-school
film making course.

2052.37.text:
So I'd like to think this isn't the end.
That there is more to come from this.
